description: Divide the length of the light ray by the domain width to get the correct traversal length fraction. Otherwise it will give incorrect redshift values along the light ray for boxes with domain width not equal to 1.
title: update light_ray.py for domain width != 1

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job! https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite/503/
content.html: All tests pass. Good job! https://tests.yt-project.org/job/yt_testsuite/503/

content.raw: LGTM; only concern is using element 0 for the width.  Seems like there's probably a way to use the `unitary` units for this somewhere, but this looks like it'll do the trick.
content.html: LGTM; only concern is using element 0 for the width. Seems like there's probably a way to use the unitary units for this somewhere, but this looks like it'll do the trick.

content.raw: @brittonsmith @chummels
content.html: Britton Smith Cameron Hummels

content.raw: Britton is on vacation.  If this needs to go in before he returns, we should proceed without him.
content.html: Britton is on vacation. If this needs to go in before he returns, we should proceed without him.

content.raw: Nice catch, @ethlau .  It looks like you've corrected the behavior for simple light rays, (ie over a single dataset), but I'm wondering if this is a problem for compound light rays too (over multiple datasets).  In looking over the code for compound datasets and `traversal_box_fraction` it looks like it might be OK as is, but this may necessitate some additional tests by @brittonsmith and me.  Anyway, nice contribution!
content.html: Nice catch, Erwin Tin-Hay Lau . It looks like you've corrected the behavior for simple light rays, (ie over a single dataset), but I'm wondering if this is a problem for compound light rays too (over multiple datasets). In looking over the code for compound datasets and traversal_box_fraction it looks like it might be OK as is, but this may necessitate some additional tests by Britton Smith and me. Anyway, nice contribution!

content.raw:
I think it might be clearer to do this conversion on `start_position` and `end_position` in `make_light_ray`. Something like:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/6581/

While ^ this patch is more verbose than the one proposed here, I think it makes the intention of the code more clear and makes it a bit easier to reason about the units here.
content.html:
I think it might be clearer to do this conversion on start_position and end_position in make_light_ray. Something like:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/6581/

While ^ this patch is more verbose than the one proposed here, I think it makes the intention of the code more clear and makes it a bit easier to reason about the units here.

content.raw:
Thanks for all the feedback and suggestions. This is just my simple hack to make the simple light ray from the ART simulation data, which have domain width larger than one. It may not work for compound light rays over multiple data sets, as @chummels pointed out. 

I was not aware of the unitary units (still learning yt...). I will try out @ngoldbaum's suggestion.
content.html:
Thanks for all the feedback and suggestions. This is just my simple hack to make the simple light ray from the ART simulation data, which have domain width larger than one. It may not work for compound light rays over multiple data sets, as Cameron Hummels pointed out.

I was not aware of the unitary units (still learning yt...). I will try out Nathan Goldbaum's suggestion.

content.raw: I'll also look to see if @ngoldbaum 's suggested code breaks any Trident business, but in general it looks like a cleaner solution.  I thought it already accepted YTArrays, but maybe I was mistaken.
content.html: I'll also look to see if Nathan Goldbaum 's suggested code breaks any Trident business, but in general it looks like a cleaner solution. I thought it already accepted YTArrays, but maybe I was mistaken.

content.raw: I think it does, I was just clarifying in the docstrings.
content.html: I think it does, I was just clarifying in the docstrings.

content.raw: I've looked through the code and `traversal_box_fraction` is already being normalized by the box size in the compound ray case
content.html: I've looked through the code and traversal_box_fraction is already being normalized by the box size in the compound ray case

content.raw: I agree that this is a more robust and safer solution.
content.html: I agree that this is a more robust and safer solution.

content.raw: ping @ethlau
content.html: ping Erwin Tin-Hay Lau

content.raw: Tested suggested code by @ngoldbaum. It returns light ray of length of one code unit, which shouldn't be.
content.html: Tested suggested code by Nathan Goldbaum. It returns light ray of length of one code unit, which shouldn't be.

content.raw: Hmm, ok. Do you have a test script you can share so I can try to debug?
content.html: Hmm, ok. Do you have a test script you can share so I can try to debug?

content.html:
Oh oops, I see a bug in my patch. Can you try this instead:

content.raw: Given that I can't easily test this, I'd be ok with merging the PR as is so the issue doesn't sit here unfixed.
content.html: Given that I can't easily test this, I'd be ok with merging the PR as is so the issue doesn't sit here unfixed.

content.raw:
I have tested with the bug corrected but the problem persists. I think the problem is in line 460 when sub_ray is computed: 

```
#!python

            sub_ray = ds.ray(sub_segment[0], sub_segment[1])

```
subs_segment is now in unitary units with the patch, but sub_ray needs to be in code units. 

I have corrected this by converting the units in segments back in code units before the sub_ray calculation

```
#!python

            my_segment['start'] = my_segment['start'].to('code_length')
            my_segment['end'] = my_segment['end'].to('code_length')

```
This seems to work fine with my data set. I hope this won't break more things.
content.html:
I have tested with the bug corrected but the problem persists. I think the problem is in line 460 when sub_ray is computed: 

            sub_ray = ds.ray(sub_segment[0], sub_segment[1])

subs_segment is now in unitary units with the patch, but sub_ray needs to be in code units.

I have corrected this by converting the units in segments back in code units before the sub_ray calculation

            my_segment['start'] = my_segment['start'].to('code_length')
            my_segment['end'] = my_segment['end'].to('code_length')

This seems to work fine with my data set. I hope this won't break more things.

content.raw:
I tried running this and got the error:


```
#!python

 File "/Users/chummels/src/yt/yt/analysis_modules/cosmological_observation/light_ray/light_ray.py", line 371, in make_light_ray
    if (start_position) and hasattr(start_position, 'units'):
ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()
```
content.html:
I tried running this and got the error:

 File "/Users/chummels/src/yt/yt/analysis_modules/cosmological_observation/light_ray/light_ray.py", line 371, in make_light_ray
    if (start_position) and hasattr(start_position, 'units'):
ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()

content.raw: You probably want to say `if start_position is not None and hasattr(start_position, 'units')`, just in case `start_position` is an ndarray.
content.html: You probably want to say if start_position is not None and hasattr(start_position, 'units'), just in case start_position is an ndarray.
